http://www.ppaction.org/campaign/fakeclinics
 
 An Indiana mother recently accompanied her daughter and her daughter's boyfriend to one of Indiana's Planned Parenthood clinics, but they unwittingly walked into a so-called "crisis pregnancy center" run by an anti-abortion group, one that shared a parking lot with the real Planned Parenthood clinic and was designed expressly to lure Planned Parenthood patients and deceive them.
 
 The group took down the girl's confidential personal information and told her to come back for her appointment, which they said would be in their "other office" (the real Planned Parenthood office nearby). When she arrived for her appointment, not only did the Planned Parenthood staff have no record of her, but the police were there. The "crisis pregnancy center" had called them, claiming that a minor was being forced to have an abortion against her will.
 
 The "crisis pregnancy center" staff then proceeded to wage a campaign of intimidation and harassment over the following days, showing up at the girl's home and calling her father's workplace. Our clinic director reports that the girl was "scared to death to leave her house." They even went to her school and urged classmates to pressure her not to have an abortion.
 
 The anti-choice movement is setting up these "crisis pregnancy centers" across the country. Some of them have neutral-sounding names and run ads that falsely promise the full range of reproductive health services, but they dispense anti-choice propaganda and intimidation instead. And according to a recent article in The New York Times, there are currently more of these centers in the U.S. than there are actual abortion providers. 
 
 What's more, these centers have received $60 million in government grants. They're being funded by our tax dollars.

 Don't you have to be inspected and have a license to be act as a psychiatrist or councilor? If the adverts are making false claims or even just misleading I'm sure there is legal action you can take rather than trying to pass a bill, there is existing legislation covering this isn't there?

There is a difference between the government authorising the funding of faith based counciling centres or even these people applying for standard funding for counciling and psychiatry services. This does not equal a rubber stamp to everything they do - they will likely require exactly the same standards as a secular one if they want to claim certain things in adverts, and whatever the case is they can not use false advertising.

 It is very easy to call yourself a "counselor". All you need is a business license. There are many out there with no academic credentials at all. (Dr. Laura is a famous example.) You certainly can take legal action if they make false claims. These exist. There is one near me called Crisis Pregnancy Center. They are all over the place. A good way to tell is they don't get picketed.

I did a search recently on abortion and came across About.com. The site had a number of abortion links, not the least of which was one decidedly anti-abortion group that was there to "counsel" women who found themselves with an unwanted pregnancy. And another that was very, very nuetral. It was only when you looked carefully at the wording along some of their facts that you realized, they, too, were anti-abortion. But of course, they didn't say they were "pro-life." They were just there to counsel women with unwanted pregnancies. Um hm.
 
 Misdirection works for these groups. It's no wonder why pro-choice advocates bring up deceit so much when speaking of anti-abortion groups. They've proven, over and over, that they'll lie to get their point across.
It is wrong to lie...thats true...but it isnt right to have an abortion either. So my advice is to do neither.
